item.title: The real me
item.description: An Elizabethan adage affirmed that ‘Truth is truth, to the end of reckoning’. The author is William Shakespeare, and even when it looks like a positivist maxim, is not, since he was not a positivist nor a scientist. That has been brought up for a reason. The truth, the reality, the real world, are challenging matters broadly discussed by both scientists and thinkers, mainly under the scope of Empiricism and Rationalism. Nevertheless, it is reflected in the definition of Science nowadays. It has been defined as comprised group of interconnected allegoric statements, meaning that when there’s a discussion about facts and theories, data and assumptions, the very real world is not the subject of it, but a set of descriptions and propositions concerning the world (Jan
